block.p: U.S. and Syria Discuss Iraq In Rare High-Level Meeting Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice met with her Syrian counterpart in the first high-level diplomatic contact between Washington and Damascus in more than two years. The meeting came during talks on Iraq in which the Bush administration is seeking the help of Iraq's neighbors to quell the violence there.

Clinton Sharpens Stand on Iraq Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton proposed that Congress repeal the authority it gave President Bush in 2002 to invade Iraq, injecting presidential politics into the Congressional debate over war funding.

A federal official whose investigations of corruption in Iraq have embarrassed the Bush administration is now being investigated himself by an oversight committee with links to the White House and by the ranking Republican on the House government reform committee.

Climate Group Urges Action The world needs to divert substantially from its main energy sources within a few decades to limit rising temperatures and seas driven by the buildup of heat-trapping emissions in the air, the top body studying climate change has concluded.

U.S. Investigates Afghan Strike The top American commander in Afghanistan said he was investigating claims that dozens of civilians were killed and wounded recently by American airstrikes in the western province of Herat. The commander said so far it appeared that ''only firing insurgents were targeted'' in the airstrike.

Florida Moves Up Primary Despite Bipartisan Threats Casting more uncertainty over the presidential nominating process for 2008, the Florida Legislature moved the state's primary up to Jan. 29, ignoring the threat of sanctions from the national Republican and Democratic Parties.

Republican Candidates Debate The 10 declared Republican presidential candidates met together for the first time in what amounted to a tentative but occasionally vibrant competition to define the party's ideology and agenda in a post-Bush era. The leading candidates offered sharply contrasting views of Mr. Bush himself.

Police Chief Speaks Out Chief William J. Bratton of the Los Angeles police said a clash between officers and demonstrators and journalists at an immigration rally on Tuesday was the ''worst incident of this type I have ever encountered in 37 years'' in law enforcement.

Ex-Official Defends Attorneys A former deputy attorney general told the House Judiciary Committee that he regarded most of the fired United States attorneys as highly competent prosecutors who should not have been dismissed. A18
Gene Linked to Heart Disease Two rival teams of scientists have discovered a common genetic variation that increases the risk of heart disease up to 60 percent in people of European descent.

Bloomberg Plans Overhaul Of City Building Code Mayor Bloomberg proposed the most comprehensive overhaul in the centuries-long history of New York City's building code, hoping to bring the code in line with less cluttered national standards and to incorporate lessons of the World Trade Center collapse. B1

Flare-Up Over Arabic School The Department of Education is considering postponing the opening of New York City's first public school dedicated to Arabic language and culture, according to several people involved in the discussions. Protests have been raised by parents and a few newspaper columnists, who have called the proposed school a madrassa, which teaches the Koran. B1

Murdoch Talks About Journal A day after the announcement that Rupert Murdoch has made a $5 billion offer for Dow Jones, publisher of the The Wall Street Journal, the media mogul discusses his plans to invest in the company's journalism. C1
High Rollers for Charity At the 2007 Robin Hood dinner, two people paid $400,000 each to sing with Aerosmith and a package that includes dinner for 10 with Mario Batali fetched $1.3 million. C1
Martha Stewart Food Line In 2008, the Martha Stewart name will adorn a line of fresh, refrigerated and frozen foods sold at Costco. C1
Walter M. Schirra Jr. One of the original Mercury Seven astronauts, he was 84. B7
Editorials: Family values, betrayed; the other boot; dirty tricks by phone; Adam Cohen on the U.S. attorney, the G.O.P. congressman and the timely job offer.
